context: Western commentators post-9/11 often perceive madaris as places of radical revivalism with a connotation of <a0_0><b5_0>anti-Americanism and radical extremism<b5_0/><a0_0/>, frequently associated in the Western press with Wahhabi attitudes toward non-Muslims. In Arabic the word madrasa simply means "school" and does not imply a political or religious affiliation, radical or otherwise. Madaris have <a1_0><b6_0>varied curricula<b6_0/><a1_0/>, and are not all religious. Some madaris in India, for example, have a <a2_0><b7_0>secularised<b7_0/><a2_0/> identity. Although early madaris were founded primarily to gain "knowledge of God" they also taught subjects such as mathematics and poetry. For example, in the Ottoman Empire, "Madrasahs had <a4_0><b9_0>seven<b9_0/><a4_0/> categories of sciences that were taught, such as: styles of writing, oral sciences like the Arabic language, grammar, rhetoric, and history and intellectual sciences, such as logic."
